context: Measurements were grouped into two multivariate data sets, one labeled as “North Sea”, the other as “Scheldt estuary”. Each variable was censored at the decision limit and reported as “<x det”, with x det the numerical value of the detection limit. A single censoring value was used for each compound throughout the study. Censoring intensities for each analyte in both data sets are given in Fig. 1 .Approach Three compounds remained uncensored: 1,1,2-trichloroethane and tetrachloroethene (“Scheldt estuary”), and o-xylene (“North Sea”). Each of these data sets was artificially censored by gradually discarding the lowest uncensored measurement from the ranked set of values. At each degree of censoring, the mean, standard deviation (SD), median and interquartile range (IQR) were estimated by several statistical procedures described below. Method performance was assessed by a relative error- or bias-term, calculated as 100 ( θ ̂ censor − θ ̂ uncensor ) θ ̂ uncensor , with  θ ̂ censor and  θ ̂ uncensor sample parameter estimates computed from censored and uncensored data sets, respectively.

The term 'analyte' refers to any substance being analyzed or measured, which includes 1,1,2,2-tetrachloroethene as part of the study's focus on environmental contaminants. However, there is no detailed discussion of the specific relationship or significance of 1,1,2,2-tetrachloroethene as an analyte beyond its inclusion in the data sets.
